results.title: The Looney, looney, looney Bugs Bunny movie
results.creator_credit: Isadore Freleng and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: A feature length film containing some of Friz Freleng’s award winning cartoons starring those wonderful cartoon character creations of Freleng’s including Bugs Bunny, Yosemite Sam, Pepe Le Pew, Porky Pig, Daffy Duck, Tweety Pie and Sylvester. The film is presented as part of an Award Ceremony honouring the classic Merrie Melodies and Looney Tunes characters beginning with Bugs Bunny in an Academy Award winning cartoon short “Knighty knight Bugs”. The program is then divided into three acts: Act I - “Satan’s waitin’” starring Yosemite Sam; Act II - “The Unmentionables” starring Bugs Bunny as Elegant Ness, co-starring Daffy Duck, Porky Pig, Tweety Pie and Sylvester along with the notorious Rocky and his gang; Act III - The Oswald Awards hosted by Bugs Bunny (a take on the Academy Awards) showing cartoon highlights of the nominees in their starring performances, including Big Bad Wolf and the Three little bops. Classic cartoons, great family entertainment. Majority of voice characterisations by Mel Blanc.

results.title: Holy smoke
results.creator_credit: Jane Campion, Jan Chapman, Saddleback Productions and Miramax Films
results.brief_description: During a backpacking holiday in India, Ruth, a young Australian woman, experiences a spiritual awakening at an ashram. Convinced that she has found peace, harmony and purpose she decides to stay on with her newfound guru, much to the horror of her family in Australia. Luring her back to suburban Sydney on false pretences they employ the services of P.J., an American ‘cult-exiter’. The deprogramming encounter that takes place over three days in a shack on an isolated outback farm becomes a battle of wits and wills over spirituality and sexuality. Returning to the themes of dysfunctional family life that she focused on in her first feature “Sweetie”, Campion employs cultural stereotypes to contrast the exotic appeal of Eastern spiritualism for the idealistic Ruth, with her family’s lack of understanding and crassness. The film’s central concern with the search for the meaning of life is juxtaposed with comedic elements drawn from the repertoire of cliched Australian ‘types’ that were a commonplace of Australian cinema in the nineties, and moments of high melodrama. Though Campion clearly demonstrated her cinematic and technical proficiency, the narrative was considered by some critics to be somewhat clumsy and overambitious.

results.title: I was a teenage werewolf
results.creator_credit: Gene Fowler Jr, Herman Cohen, American International Pictures (AIP) and Sunset Productions
results.brief_description: Tony Rivers (Michael Landon) is an angry, troubled teen who shows misguided aggression towards his friends and family. Sensing something is awry, Tony agrees to see psychologist Dr Brandon, a skilled hypnotist. Unbeknownst to Tony however, Brandon is hell-bent on seeing Tony regress to a primal state under his influence. When a teen is killed, seemingly by an animal, the facts are soon uncovered - Tony is a werewolf. Despite its B-movie origins and stock characterisations, “I was a teenage werewolf” plays as a sharp analogy for the trials, physical transformations, alienation and inherent difficulties of puberty.

results.title: The Little vampire
results.creator_credit: Uli Edel, Richard Klaus and Vampire Productions
results.brief_description: An only child receives a change of lifestyle when his father builds a golf course at the place where it all started, Scotland. Young Tony (Jonathan Lipnicki) is bullied at school, has a recurring dream about vampires and is miserable and without friends. His dreams prove founded when he is visited by a young boy from his dreams who turns out to be a vampire. Weak and unable to fly, Rudolph is taken care of by Tony who cares for the ailing bloodsucker and the two become friends. Tony educates Rudolph (Rollo Weeks) in the mores of life in the 21st century and Rudolph shares his life story - his family, the Sackville-Baggs are part of a vampire community cursed as lost souls until a powerful amulet can be restored to lift the curse. Tony joins the quest, even though it will mean losing the circle of friends he has found in the process. Based on the novels by Angela Sommer-Bodenburg. Cast also includes Richard E Grant, Jim Carter, Alice Krige and Anna Popplewell.

results.title: Wombling free
results.creator_credit: Lionel Jeffries, Ian Shand and Rank Organisation Film Productions
results.brief_description: Based on the original Womble Books and characters created by Elizabeth Beresford and on the BBC television series designed by Ivor Wood and produced by Graham Clutterbuck, this feature length film brings those dear fat furry Wombles to life and into our hearts. Since Adam and Eve, the Wombles’ mission is to keep the world a tidy place, to pick up the mess that human beings leave behind and to try and make human beings listen to the message that they should not litter the environment or create pollution of any kind. “Wombling free” takes us to England and the home of the Wombles of Wimbledon Common where we meet Madame Cholet, the most famous Womble cook in the whole world, Tomsk and Bungo, fat, greedy and lazy Orinoco, Wellington, a clever inventor who lacks confidence and Great Uncle Bulgaria (who narrates the story). Only those who believe in the Wombles can see the Wombles and whilst attempting to get the human beings to listen to his message of anti-litter anti-pollution, Bungo makes friends with a young schoolgirl named Felicity “Kim” Frogmorton who helps Bungo in convincing other human beings, including her parents, that Wombles do indeed exist. There are plots and sub-plots but this delightful story is filled with magic, music, song and dance and lots of funny fat furry characters who manage to spread the serious message of caring for the environment in a light-hearted, easy to understand way. Cast includes David Tomlinson, Frances de la Tour, Bernard Spear, Yasuko Nagazumi and Bonnie Langford as Kim.

results.title: Road to Singapore
results.creator_credit: Victor Schertzinger, Harlan Thompson and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Comedy venture from the team of Bob Hope and Bing Crosby, “The Road to Singapore” is a sprightly film that consistently amuses and entertains. Crosby plays Josh Mallon, the irresponsible son of a shipping magnate who would rather hang with his carefree sailor buddy Ace Lannigan (Hope) than realise his father’s lofty aspirations for him. On the eve of his wedding to long-time fiancee Gloria, Josh hightails it to Singapore with Ace in tow. Once there, the boys’ friendship falls under a cloud when they’re both attracted to saucy nightclub singer Mima (Dorothy Lamour) who goes on the lam from her possessive boyfriend Caesar (Anthony Quinn). As the boys slug it out for Mima’s affections, Gloria turns up in search of her wayward husband to be. The exoticism, spontaneity, lushness and passion of the East is contrasted with the cool, emotionless Western moneyed arena of Gloria’s world. Watch for an intriguing scene in which Crosby and Hope go ‘native’. This successful film, featuring several musical interludes, spawned six more “Road to…” movies starring Hope and Crosby.

results.title: The Little rascals
results.creator_credit: Penelope Spheeris, Gerald Molen, Bill Oakes, Michael King, King World and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: Spanky, Alfalfa, and the other ‘little rascals’ made famous in the Hal Roach ‘Our Gang’ shorts of the 1920s and 1930s, test the boundaries of friendship when Alfalfa falls head over heels for Darla. As a member of the “He-Man Womun Haters Club’, Alfalfa has sworn to hate women, and must hide his crush. A task he believes will be simple, as the boys are focused on the upcoming go-cart derby, and their prize-winning go-cart ‘The Blur’. Unfortunately Alfalfa’s best friend and club president Spanky discovers his friend has breached the number one club rule, and attempts to sabotage the relationship before it begins, starting a chain reaction of comical mistakes and misunderstandings. Features cameos by Whoopi Goldberg, Donald Trump, Mel Brooks, Daryl Hannah and Reba McEntire.

results.title: The Chipmunk adventure
results.creator_credit: Janice Karman, Ross Bagdasarian, Bagdasarian Productions and Samuel Goldwyn Company
results.brief_description: Join the high-flying adventures of Simon, Theodore and Alvin in their first full length feature movie. The fun begins when Dave leaves the Chipmunks behind when he goes to Europe. Alvin dreams of his own world travel and convinces his brothers to enter a hot air balloon race around the world against the Chipettes. As the two balloons compete for a $100,000 prize, they unwittingly assist a pair of international diamond smugglers. Alvin and the gang get more than their fair share of spills, thrills and excitement backed by a great rock soundtrack sung by the Chipmunks themselves.

results.title: Hard core logo = Hardcore logo
results.creator_credit: Bruce McDonald, Brian Dennis, Christine Heabler, Shadow Shows and Terminal City Pictures
results.brief_description: This comic mockumentary about a punk band that embarks on a disastrous final comeback tour, begs comparison to the seminal rock-mockumentary “This is Spinal Tap” (1983). Yet while both films mime the cliches of the rock and roll lifestyle with hilarious results, “Hard Core Logo” is less of an out-and-out farce than its predecessor. Its tongue-in-cheek exploration of small time rock celebrity and friendship gone sour, is tinged by a darker, ruder, more nihlistic undertone characteristic of punk rock’s ethos. After re-uniting for a benefit performance fifteen years after their acrimonious breakup, the members of legendary Vancouver punk rock band Hard Core Logo decide to do one last farewell tour across western Canada, accompanied by a documentary film crew. As soon as they hit the road the hostilities between the egomaniacal lead singer and the charismatic guitarist - the only band member with a future in music - that originally split the band quickly rise to the surface again. Meanwhile having forgotten his medication, the bass player is struggling with his mental stability, while Pipefitter, the redneck stoned drummer, is oblivious to everything. Predictably the tour soon declines into melodrama and ultimately, tragedy. Cast includes Hugh Dillon, Callum Keith Rennie, Bernie Coulson, John Pyper-Ferguson.

Its tongue-in-cheek exploration of small time rock celebrity and friendship gone sour, is tinged by a darker, ruder, more nihlistic undertone characteristic of punk rock’s ethos. After re-uniting for a benefit performance fifteen years after their acrimonious breakup, the members of legendary Vancouver punk rock band Hard Core Logo decide to do one last farewell tour across western Canada, accompanied by a documentary film crew. As soon as they hit the road the hostilities between the egomaniacal lead singer and the charismatic guitarist - the only band member with a future in music - that originally split the band quickly rise to the surface again. Meanwhile having forgotten his medication, the bass player is struggling with his mental stability, while Pipefitter, the redneck stoned drummer, is oblivious to everything. Predictably the tour soon declines into melodrama and ultimately, tragedy. Cast includes Hugh Dillon, Callum Keith Rennie, Bernie Coulson, John Pyper-Ferguson.

results.title: It's elementary: talking about gay issues in school
results.creator_credit: Debra Chasnoff, Helen S. Cohen and Women's Educational Media
results.brief_description: It’s elementary provides parents and educators with information and advice on tackling gay and lesbian issues in schools. The documentary uses classroom footage and interviews with parents and teachers to examine what happens when homosexuality is discussed in the classroom. A wide range of teaching techniques and results are observed in six American schools of varying age levels, geographical locations, socio-economic and ethnic backgrounds. Issues such as homophobia, harassment, stereotypes, the law and family are discussed with students via brainstorming, storytelling, writing and guest speakers. The overriding relevancy of discussing homosexuality in schools and the appropriateness of the subject matter for various age groups is questioned and reinforced. The controversies, debates and opinions displayed in “It’s elementary” make fascinating viewing for a wide audience.
